questions.question: What is Service Cloud in Salesforce?

options.A: A Salesforce solution designed for customer service and support, providing tools for case management, omni-channel routing, and knowledge management.
options.B: A marketing automation product focused on email campaigns.
options.C: A data warehousing product for analytics outside CRM.
options.D: A developer tool for building custom Apex frameworks.

questions.explanation: Service Cloud is Salesforce's product for customer support with cases, routing, knowledge, and agent workspace features.

questions.question: What is a Case in Service Cloud?

options.A: A knowledge article used by support agents.
options.B: A record that tracks customer issues, questions, or requests.
options.C: A report for service KPIs.
options.D: A marketing campaign member record.

questions.explanation: Cases capture customer issues and are the primary record type for support processes.

questions.question: What are Case Assignment Rules?

options.A: Manual steps agents take to close cases.
options.B: Rules that automatically assign cases to users or queues based on predefined criteria.
options.C: Email templates for case notifications.
options.D: A special report type for case distribution.

questions.explanation: Assignment rules evaluate case fields and route new cases to the correct user or queue automatically.

questions.question: What is a Case Queue?

options.A: An automation that closes cases after SLA breach.
options.B: A permission set used for agents.
options.C: A holding area where unassigned cases are stored until an agent takes ownership.
options.D: A kind of knowledge article classification.

questions.explanation: Queues let teams share work by holding unassigned records which members can claim.

questions.question: What is Omni-Channel in Service Cloud?

options.A: A feature that intelligently routes work items (cases, chats, tasks) to the right agent based on skills, capacity, and availability.
options.B: A UI layout tool for the Service Console.
options.C: A workflow engine for approval processes.
options.D: A reporting dashboard for case trends.

questions.explanation: Omni-Channel routes incoming work in real time to agents based on capacity and routing/configuration rules.

questions.question: Difference between Omni-Channel and Case Assignment Rules?

options.A: Both are identical features and interchangeable.
options.B: Case Assignment Rules → Assign cases to users/queues at creation. Omni-Channel → Routes real-time work dynamically based on agent workload.
options.C: Omni-Channel only works for email; Assignment Rules only for phone.
options.D: Assignment Rules are only available in Sandbox.

questions.explanation: Assignment Rules run at creation to set owners; Omni-Channel actively routes and balances work items by agent capacity/skills.

questions.question: What are Entitlements in Service Cloud?

options.A: A visual theme for the console.
options.B: An event streaming mechanism.
options.C: A report type for CSAT scores.
options.D: Define the level of support customers are entitled to, such as response times and resolution times.

questions.explanation: Entitlements formalize promised support levels and are enforced via milestones/SLA tracking.

questions.question: What is a Milestone in Service Cloud?

options.A: A type of case status used only in Communities.
options.B: A Chatter post on case progress.
options.C: A measurable step within an entitlement process, e.g., 'First Response within 2 hours.'
options.D: A Salesforce license category.

questions.explanation: Milestones are timed checkpoints used with entitlements to ensure SLA commitments are met.

questions.question: What is a Service Level Agreement (SLA) in Salesforce?

options.A: A dashboard that visualizes agent activity.
options.B: An agreement defining the time frame within which a case must be responded to or resolved, implemented using entitlements and milestones.
options.C: A security policy for API access.
options.D: A template for email notifications.

questions.explanation: SLAs define expected response and resolution windows and are enforced with entitlements and milestone tracking.

questions.question: What is a Knowledge Base in Service Cloud?

options.A: A repository of articles and FAQs that help agents and customers resolve issues quickly.
options.B: A list of open cases for an account.
options.C: A queue of unresolved cases.
options.D: A tool for scheduling service jobs.

questions.explanation: Knowledge stores structured articles that agents and customers can search to find solutions.

questions.question: Difference between Salesforce Knowledge and Solution?

options.A: Solution → Advanced knowledge base; Knowledge → Legacy Q&A.
options.B: They are both identical names for the same feature.
options.C: Solution (Legacy) → Simple Q&A for cases. Knowledge → Advanced knowledge base with publishing workflows, versioning, and multi-channel access.
options.D: Knowledge is only available in Classic UI.

questions.explanation: Knowledge replaces legacy Solutions with richer content lifecycle, channels, and versioning capabilities.

questions.question: What is a Service Console?

options.A: A command-line tool to manage cases.
options.B: A unified workspace for agents that allows handling multiple cases, chats, and customer interactions in one view.
options.C: A separate mobile-only app for reporting.
options.D: A template library for page layouts.

questions.explanation: The Service Console provides an agent-focused UI to efficiently handle multiple interactions and related data.

questions.question: What is a Case Escalation Rule?

options.A: A rule that permanently deletes old cases.
options.B: A way to assign cases to campaigns.
options.C: Rules that automatically escalate cases to higher support levels if they remain unresolved within a certain time.
options.D: A deprecated feature replaced by queues.

questions.explanation: Escalation rules monitor milestone/time thresholds and reassign or notify stakeholders when SLAs are breached.

questions.question: What are Macros in Service Cloud?

options.A: Automated actions that let agents perform repetitive tasks (like sending standard responses) in one click.
options.B: A type of Apex trigger used for cases.
options.C: A format for knowledge article versions.
options.D: A rule-based routing engine.

questions.explanation: Macros automate sequences of actions an agent would normally perform manually to speed case handling.

questions.question: What is Live Agent (Chat) in Salesforce?

options.A: A batch process for closing cases overnight.
options.B: A back-end API for knowledge articles.
options.C: A real-time chat feature that connects customers with support agents through websites or apps.
options.D: A reporting snapshot tool.

questions.explanation: Live Agent enables real-time web chat between customers and agents for immediate support.

questions.question: What is Einstein Bots in Service Cloud?

options.A: A manual chat script stored as a text file.
options.B: A visual theme manager for the Service Console.
options.C: AI-powered chatbots that handle routine customer queries before handing them off to live agents.
options.D: A deprecated integration for SMS only.

questions.explanation: Einstein Bots automate common interactions using AI and can escalate to human agents when needed (correct content under C).

questions.question: What is Case Feed?

options.A: A real-time newsfeed of company announcements.
options.B: A scheduled export of case data.
options.C: A dashboard widget for SLA metrics.
options.D: A Chatter-based collaboration feature that allows agents to communicate and update case details in real-time.

questions.explanation: Case Feed provides a timeline and collaboration tools (Chatter, emails, updates) for each case record.

questions.question: What is Email-to-Case?

options.A: A feature that automatically converts customer emails into cases.
options.B: A tool for sending mass emails to customers.
options.C: An Apex library for parsing emails in tests.
options.D: A way to export emails to CSV.

questions.explanation: Email-to-Case creates case records from incoming emails so support can manage requests centrally.

questions.question: What is Web-to-Case?

options.A: A feature allowing customers to submit cases directly from a website form.
options.B: A connector for external social networks.
options.C: A data extraction tool for knowledge articles.
options.D: A method to convert web pages to PDF.

questions.explanation: Web-to-Case generates HTML forms that submit case data to Salesforce, creating cases from website submissions (correct content under A).

questions.question: What is Social Customer Service?

options.A: A tool to schedule social posts for marketing.
options.B: A feature that lets companies respond to customer inquiries from social media (Twitter, Facebook, etc.).
options.C: A reporting plugin for social KPIs only.
options.D: A legacy feature retired from Salesforce.

questions.explanation: Social Customer Service connects social channels to Service Cloud so agents can respond to and track social inquiries as cases.

questions.question: What are Service Contracts in Salesforce?

options.A: A type of lead status.
options.B: A dashboard for service metrics.
options.C: Agreements that define support terms and cover customers, often linked with entitlements.
options.D: A permission set for external partners.

questions.explanation: Service Contracts formalize the support agreement with a customer and are typically associated with entitlements and milestones (correct content under C).

questions.question: What is Field Service Lightning (FSL)?

options.A: A Salesforce product that extends Service Cloud for managing mobile workforce, scheduling, and field operations.
options.B: A tool for building Lightning pages only.
options.C: A schema modeling tool for service objects.
options.D: A deprecated mobile app for agents.

questions.explanation: FSL provides dispatch, scheduling, mobile workforce management, and offline capabilities for field technicians.

questions.question: How does Knowledge Base integrate with Cases?

options.A: Agents can search and attach knowledge articles directly to case records for quick resolutions.
options.B: Knowledge Base is unrelated to case resolution.
options.C: Knowledge articles are automatically converted to cases.
options.D: Cases are archived inside the Knowledge Base.

questions.explanation: Agents use the knowledge search to find articles and attach or link them to cases to help resolve issues quickly (correct content under A).

questions.question: What is the use of Service Analytics?

options.A: Provides dashboards and reports on KPIs like case resolution time, first contact resolution, agent productivity.
options.B: A tool to schedule Omni-Channel routes only.
options.C: A code profiler for Apex in the Service Console.
options.D: A component for embedding marketing analytics.

questions.explanation: Service analytics offers reporting and dashboards focused on service KPIs to measure team performance and SLA adherence (correct content under A).

questions.question: Best practices in Service Cloud implementation?

options.A: Automate case routing and escalation; use macros for efficiency; enable Omni-Channel for workload balancing; leverage Knowledge Base for faster resolutions.
options.B: Avoid using entitlements or SLAs to keep processes flexible.
options.C: Force agents to handle all channels manually without routing.
options.D: Disable Case Feed and collaboration to reduce noise.

questions.explanation: Implementing automation, routing, knowledge, and collaboration improves agent productivity and customer outcomes; the other options reduce effectiveness.
